bestBHT.bht: No society can stand when turned against itself; such intestine war is suicidal. The works I do are destructive of Satan's kingdom, so it is absurd to suggest that I am in league with him. He is divided, for if he is casting himself out, there must have been a previous division. Satan's wicked nature ensures that there is no internal struggle between good and evil within him. His kingdom is constantly at odds with the kingdom of God, making any notion of acting against his own interests weak and malicious.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: No organized society can stand—whether kingdom, city, or household—when turned against itself; such intestine war is suicidal."
But the works I do are destructive of Satan's kingdom."
That I should be in league with Satan, therefore, is incredible and absurd.
Marvin Vincent: He is divided [εμερισθη] . Lit., "he was divided." If he is casting himself out, there must have been a previous division.
Philip Schaff: A man might be at war within, but even then, the outward acts would not necessarily be in opposition.
Satan is utterly wicked, hence good and evil do not strive within him, and his fighting against himself is not to be imagined.
Satan is a person; that he has a kingdom; while the whole argument assumes that this kingdom is in constant antagonism to the kingdom of God.
John Gill: He acts contrary to his own interest, which is to keep possession of the bodies and souls of men; and consequently it must, in course, be subversive of his power and dominion.

These words suggest that there is a form of government among the devils, who are united in one body, under one head; and whose unity and concord are their greatest strength, as in all other governments.

Since Satan, who is so cunning and crafty, can never be thought to act such an opposite part to himself, subversive of his kingdom and government; the weakness, and maliciousness of such a suggestion, must be clear and evident to all.
John Wesley: How shall his kingdom be established — Does not that subtle spirit know thin is not the way to establish his kingdom?

bhtAttempts.bht: No society can sustain itself when it is divided and turned against itself, as this would lead to self-destruction. Likewise, it is unthinkable that I, Jesus, would be in league with Satan, for the works I do are in direct opposition to his kingdom. Satan, being utterly wicked, does not possess the internal struggle between good and evil, so the idea of him fighting against himself is absurd. Moreover, Satan has his own kingdom, and it is clear that it is in constant antagonism to the kingdom of God. Thus, any suggestion that Satan would act contrary to his own interests and subvert his own power is both weak and malicious. Surely, Satan, being so cunning, knows that this is not the way to establish his kingdom.

No organized society can stand when turned against itself; such intestine war is suicidal. But the works I do are destructive of Satan's kingdom. That I should be in league with Satan, therefore, is incredible and absurd. He is divided. If he is casting himself out, there must have been a previous division. Satan is utterly wicked, hence good and evil do not strive within him. Satan has a kingdom, and it is in constant antagonism to the kingdom of God.

No society can sustain itself when divided, for such internal conflict leads to self-destruction. It is inconceivable that I, Jesus, would align myself with Satan, given that my actions directly oppose his kingdom. Satan is utterly wicked and does not struggle between good and evil. He has his own kingdom that perpetually opposes the kingdom of God. Any suggestion that Satan would act against his own interests and subvert his power is weak and groundless.

No society can stand when turned against itself; such intestine war is suicidal. The works I do are destructive of Satan's kingdom, so it is absurd to suggest that I am in league with him. He is divided, for if he is casting himself out, there must have been a previous division. Satan's wicked nature ensures that there is no internal struggle between good and evil within him. His kingdom is constantly at odds with the kingdom of God, making any notion of acting against his own interests weak and malicious.

No society can stand when turned against itself; such intestine war is suicidal. The works I do are destructive of Satan's kingdom, so it is absurd to suggest that I am in league with him. He is divided, for if he is casting himself out, there must have been a previous division. Satan's kingdom is in constant antagonism to the kingdom of God. Any notion of acting against his own interests is weak and malicious.
